acqinfo.p: These records were transferred to the State Law Library from the Office of the Clerk to the State Law Library in 2006.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: In the nineteenth century, lawyers were admitted to the bar by the judges of the courts in which they intended to practice. The court required written recommendations from practicing lawyers pertaining to the knowledge and character of the applicant. Beginning in the 1890s, applicants were also required to request certification from the Supreme Court of Appeals to take a state bar exam. Attorneys who were members of the bar in other jurisdictions were required to produce two affidavits of their good standing with that bar.

An act approved by the General Assembly March 14, 1910, established the Virginia Board of Bar Examiners and authorized it to license lawyers and determine the qualifications of applicants who wished to take the bar examination. The Board served under the auspices of the Supreme Court of Appeals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains letters to the Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia requesting certification to take the bar exam, 1897-1909. Most of the files include recommendations from members of the bar attesting to the character and knowledge of the applicant.
The letters are arranged chronologically and alphabetically within each year.
The collection also contains two folders of correspondence, 1902-1929, from attorneys licensed to practice in other states requesting admission to the Virginia bar.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Law license applications, 1898-1899, and failed bar examinations, 1903-1906, were likely tranferred to the Library of Virginia in 1981 by the Clerk of the Supreme Court of Virginia and can be found there in the collection, Records of the Supreme Court of Appeals, 1871-1914 (accession number) 31211.

scopecontent.p: This series contains subject files documenting swearing-in ceremonies and investitures. It contains invitations, programs, oaths of office, transcripts of ceremonies, speeches and remarks, and sometimes seating charts and ceremony planning notes.
